review_title: Nice place to work but it depends who you are working with
job_title: Community Support Worker in Sidcup, England
pros: Some co workers are the nicest people you will ever come across
cons: Administration doesn’t care about ground staff.

job_title: Care Support Worker in Chertsey, England
pros: Can get a lot of hours (as no one wants to work for them)
cons: Pay is nothing special. training of staff sets a mediocre pace and precedent - clients are neglected. Racism between staff. Poor equipment. Not organised.

pros: No micro management from managers as they don’t care
cons:
Management 
Working environment 
Lack of training 
Lies being told about working environment

job_title: Learning and Development in Sidcup, England
pros: The people who I work with are values driven. The CEO Jo Land is a lovely person who really cares
cons: Some of the senior management needs to change their mindset and behaviours. Internal progression is very slow to non existant. Very poor on this side.

job_title: Assistant Service Manager in London, England
pros: They hire great people and the people you support are brilliant characters
cons: Very cheep software, computers from 2005 and houses that are in bad condition. Training provided is the bare minimum to be legal, and you’ll get it six months after you start. Despite dozens of different teams somehow managers only get given more work from them, not less. Safety of residents completely relies on having a good manager, managers are often given too many houses to handle. Residents and staff deserve better.

pros:
New opportunities
If looking for a job with positive impact
cons:
Challenging
Demands from senior level staff
Work/life balance hard to achieve
Long hours

pros: It helps improve experience within the learning disability setting and how best to support people with learning disability.
cons: Poor staff management and not enough opportunity

job_title: Learning & Development Administrator in Sidcup, England
pros: Friendly workplace environment and great management structure.
cons: No benefits as a part time employee

job_title: Resourcing Business Partner in Sidcup, England
pros:
Coming up to my fourth month of being with the organisation and though the role is hugely challenging, the people I work with, the people we support and the ethos of the company makes every day worth getting out of bed for.  

The support that I receive from my peers and the autonomy to try and make a real change is like a a breath of fresh air.  

The training is invaluable and sets you on the path you want to be going in.  Other than a great team I have working for me as well, I could not ask for a better Manager who fully supports me and is always there for solid council.
cons: I have found no cons as yet, but I do not intend to go looking for them either

pros: Nice staff. Opportunities for training. For the right person, this could be a good company to work for.
cons: Focus too much on saving money, especially when it isn't theirs to save. Managers can be hit or miss. Ours was abusive to staff and users, even calling the users animals in front of staff, but fortunately, after frequent reporting, she was put under investigation and was told she won't be back.

job_title: Support Worker, Adults With Learning & Physical Disabilities in Maidstone, England
pros:
Good opportunities into management
Shift work so flexible to staff needs
Support vulnerable adults in a positive way, huge job satisfaction
Pay relatively good
Annual leave allowance more than most companies
Good pension scheme
Brilliant training - learning & development team top notch!
cons:
Due to the nature of my role as a frontline support worker It can prove highly stressful at times & due to policies & procedures a lot of jumping through hoops to get anything done. Both of these ate probably more a hazard of the job itself rather than the company.
My manager, although lovely, wasn't the most supportive, but the company framework does allow you to easily seek the help & advice from more senior managers without any bad feeling.

pros:
Avenues offer opportunities to people who are willing to go up the ladder in the care industry.
They offer very good training and there is always some one you can talk to  in case of anything.
cons: The pay could be revised to attract the right people especially in challenging services; pay should be benched around that as challenging services struggle to recruit due to the nature of the job.

pros:
Worklife Balance - family friendly

Feeling like making a difference to peoples lives even though not working directly in operations or on front line.

Great people.

Well Lead.

Great place to learn and acquire skills not limited to the role you are employed.
cons: Being a charity can often have an impact on available resource or place scrutiny upon salaries etc compared to London rates although fully understandable as to why.

pros:
Provide fantastic services for users
Committed and brilliant support staff
Good benefits
Flexible
Excellent trainng
cons:
Top heavy and senior managers get increases whilst others do not
Need to make better business decisions to ensure a profit is made so that staff can receive increases
Nepotism

pros: It is a very relatively stable and consistent organisation. Staff training is a positive syndrome
cons: No promotion and no pay increase
